articles.title: FEBRUARY IN THE YEAR 1979
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's calendar of events for February and March 1979. It details various activities including club star parties, general meetings with guest speakers on topics like the Moonwatch program and a potential Venus probe, board meetings, and indoor star parties. Key astronomical events such as a solar eclipse and a lunar graze occultation of Aldebaran are also highlighted, alongside the announcement of the first annual Don Machholz Messier Marathon.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS                    1-18-79
articles.summary: In early 1979, there are no new comets brighter than magnitude 12, but Comet Meier is expected to become visible in March at magnitude 10. The article also reviews 1978, noting 18 labeled comets, including 7 discovered by amateur astronomers, 4 by professionals, and 7 recovered by professionals.

articles.title: Discoveries made by Amateurs
articles.summary: This document lists comets discovered by amateur astronomers during 1978, detailing the comet's designation, the discoverer's name, country of origin, discovery date, and estimated magnitude. Notable discoverers include William Bradfield from Australia and Rolf Meier from Canada. It highlights significant contributions of amateurs to astronomical discoveries.

articles.title: Discoveries made by Professionals
articles.summary: This document lists professional astronomical discoveries made in 1978. It details the discoverer's name, their country of origin, the date of discovery, and an associated numerical value, likely a magnitude or count. The table highlights contributions from researchers in Switzerland, Chile, the United Kingdom, and the U.S.A.

articles.title: Recoveries of Returning Comets
articles.summary: This document provides a tabular listing of several comets recovered in 1978, detailing their names, discoverers, countries, dates of recovery, and apparent magnitudes at the time of observation. Additionally, it includes a brief historical note on comets that have been positively identified during total solar eclipses, highlighting the Tewfik comet and an unnamed comet from 1948.

articles.title: EDITORIAL
articles.summary: The editor addresses recurring complaints that the club's Bulletin primarily features active members, explaining that she cannot represent those who do not participate or submit content. She highlights her efforts to involve less active members and clarifies that she has never rejected contributions, but faces a lack of willingness from members to create content. The editor urges readers to provide direct feedback and suggestions to improve the Bulletin and ensure its continued production.

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: The "Blurbs" section announces the "First Annual Messier Marathon," a new astronomy magazine "Star and Sky," and a job opening at the Morrison Planetarium. It also details upcoming club events like an eclipse experience show-and-tell and informational meetings, along with updates on club administration, such as a discount on Vehrenberg's Atlas and the nomination of Don Machholz for an award. The editor, Penny, provides insights into bulletin production and thanks members for their help with club activities like mailing label preparation.

articles.title: Question of the Month: Why do you like astronomy? What do you want out of it?
articles.summary: This article presents a 'Question of the Month' asking various individuals why they enjoy astronomy and what they hope to gain from it. Responses range widely, including the humble feeling of viewing distant galaxies, the enjoyment of star parties and community, the intellectual challenge of learning, the desire for perfect observing conditions, and even humorous or personal aspirations. The article highlights the diverse motivations and interests within the astronomy community.

articles.title: SPECIAL MENTION
articles.summary: This article is a heartfelt thank-you from "Penny" to Bob Schaick, her unofficial instructor in the multi-year process of making her first 6-inch telescope mirror. Penny details Bob's extensive guidance, from teaching basic grinding techniques and troubleshooting scratches, to a late-night parabolizing session and arranging for free aluminization. Bob's dedication, selflessness, and expertise were crucial to Penny successfully completing her mirror, fostering a deep appreciation for his mentorship.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed schedule of dates and times in Pacific Standard Time (PST) when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will transit the meridian. This information serves as a guide for astronomers and enthusiasts planning to observe this prominent Jovian feature. Additionally, the document references "SKY WATCH by Fred Braniff" and includes an image of a crossword puzzle.

articles.title: Clues Down
articles.summary: This document, titled "Clues Down," presents a list of 19 numbered clues for what appears to be a word puzzle, such as a crossword. The clues cover a range of topics, predominantly focusing on astronomy (e.g., celestial objects, planetary features, constellations) and optical instruments, along with some general knowledge terms.

articles.title: Clues Across
articles.summary: The document features a list of astronomy-themed crossword clues covering various celestial objects, astronomical concepts, and equipment. It also includes an opinion piece by Ed Schell, who discusses his personal reconciliation of science and religion, advocating for a belief in a God who initiated the universe through a Big Bang and natural laws, including evolution, while rejecting both strict random chance theory and literal biblical creationism.

articles.title: General Meeting
articles.summary: The first general meeting of 1979 for AASJ members attracted 154 attendees at the Rosicrucian Planetarium, despite an initial lockout. The agenda included discussions on new publications like 'Star and Sky' and the 'Messier Album', sign-ups for the Messier Marathon, and plans for a bus trip to upcoming eclipses. Dr. Gregory Ryan and Jim Van Nuland delivered talks on Copernicus and the ephemeris, respectively, amidst humorous observations about latecomers.

articles.title: Secretary's Library
articles.summary: The article announces the final list of books and pamphlets available in the club library for members, with Cathy Pinheiro as the contact for inquiries and check-outs. It also reports on a surprisingly successful and productive board meeting where several club activities and administrative matters, such as Treasurer's reports, public events, and future conferences, were discussed and decisions were made.

articles.title: CHICO OBSERVATORY
articles.summary: Chico Observatory announced an Aldebaran Penumbra graze event scheduled for just after midnight on March 4-5. Despite the low 5-degree elevation, the 1.1 magnitude star should be visible with binoculars from the IOTA/SCAA site near Dixon, California, provided the sky is clear. Interested observers are advised to contact Jim Van Nuland for further details.

articles.title: ADS ADS ADS ADS
articles.summary: This document features classified advertisements, including a Celestron 90 spotting scope and a Celestron 8 telescope for sale, along with a request for a ride to solar eclipses. Additionally, it contains a collection of unrelated, brief, and often humorous quotes attributed to various individuals.

articles.title: THE MESSIER MARATHON - Sponsored Yearly by the AANC/SJAA
articles.summary: This article announces the inaugural Messier Marathon in 1979, an annual event sponsored by the AANC/SJAA designed for observers to view as many Messier objects as possible in a single night during late March/early April. Held at Don Machholz's comet hunting site on Loma Prieta Mt., the marathon welcomes all interested individuals, including those aiming for the AANC Messier Award, and provides details on location, time, and participation rules.

articles.title: The MESSIER MARATHON - Notes about the Catalogue
articles.summary: This document provides notes and practical advice for participating in a Messier Marathon, detailing a catalogue of 110 Messier objects, including special considerations for certain entries and AANC award requirements. It outlines the catalogue's organization into 13 sky zones, provides Epoch 1980 coordinates for setting circles, and lists useful bright stars for alignment. Participants are advised to bring a notepad for detailed observations, and a bibliography of recommended Messier study resources is included.

articles.title: Page 1
articles.summary: This document is a catalog listing numerous Messier deep-sky objects, organized into several 'Areas.' For each object, it provides detailed astronomical data including NGC number, 1980 RA/Dec coordinates, constellation, apparent magnitude, size, object type (e.g., spiral galaxy, open cluster, planetary nebula), and concise descriptive notes. It serves as an observational guide for various celestial phenomena.

articles.title: MESSIER MARATHON
articles.summary: This document outlines an extensive observing list for a 'Messier Marathon,' detailing a significant number of Messier objects. For each object, it provides crucial astronomical data such as NGC numbers, celestial coordinates, constellations, magnitudes, sizes, types (e.g., globular clusters, open clusters, nebulae), and descriptive notes. The list is systematically organized into celestial 'Areas' and credits multiple contributors, serving as a comprehensive guide for observers.

articles.title: Key to abreviations used in catalogue:
articles.summary: This document serves as a key to common abbreviations used in astronomical catalogues. It defines terms such as Messier number (M), Right Ascension (RA), Declination (Dec), Constellation (Con), New General Catalogue (NGC), and Magnitude (Mg). This reference is crucial for interpreting astronomical data presented in a compact format.

articles.title: Other Notes:
articles.summary: This document outlines abbreviations for various astronomical object types, including open clusters, globular clusters, diffuse/gaseous nebulae, planetary nebulae, spiral galaxies, and elliptical galaxies. It also notes that object sizes are given in minutes of arc and mentions its place within a larger 'Suggested Search Sequence SJAA-AANC'.

articles.title: AANC Messier Club
articles.summary: The AANC Messier Club aims to encourage observational astronomy among amateurs by recognizing those who observe Messier objects. Participants can earn a plaque for spotting all 107 objects or a parchment for 75 or more. Rules include registering with the AANC, completing the observations within two years using one's own telescope, and recording the details of each sighting.
